title: 103_s653
content: The Act titled "Semiautomatic Assault Weapon Violence Prevention Act of 1993" prohibits semiautomatic assault weapons. The Act titled "Semiautomatic Assault Weapon Violence Prevention Act of 1993" defines a semiautomatic assault weapon as certain specified firearms. The Act "Semiautomatic Assault Weapon Violence Prevention Act of 1993" lists various firearms including MAC-11, Colt AR-15, Encom MP-9, Fabrique Nationale FN/FAL, Feather AT-9, Franchi SPAS-12, Intratec TEC-9, Israeli UZI, Iver Johnson Enforcer 3000, Norinco Avtomat Kalashnikovs, Steyr AUG, and USAS-12. The Act lists various firearms including revolving-cylinder shotguns like the Street Sweeper or Striker 12, semiautomatic firearms designated as assault weapons, and excludes firearms like Remington Model 1100 shotgun, Remington Model 7400 rifle, Mossberg Model 5500 shotgun, HK Model 300 rifle, Marlin Model 9 camp carbine, Browning High-Power rifle, Remington Nylon 66 auto loading rifle, and manually operated bolt action firearms. The Act prohibits the transfer or possession of semiautomatic assault weapons, with exceptions for certain entities. The Act prohibits the transfer or possession of semiautomatic assault weapons, with exceptions for certain entities, including licensed manufacturers or importers for testing purposes. The Secretary is authorized to designate semiautomatic assault weapons. The Secretary, in consultation with the Attorney General, annually determines if additional semiautomatic firearms should be designated as assault weapons. Criteria for designation include rifles, pistols, or shotguns that are not suitable for sporting purposes. Semiautomatic assault weapons are firearms that are not suitable for sporting purposes, have the ability to accept a detachable magazine, and possess at least 2 out of 5 specific characteristics, such as a folding stock, pistol grip, bayonet mount, flash suppressor, or grenade launcher. This classification also applies to semiautomatic pistols that meet similar criteria. A semiautomatic assault weapon must have at least 2 of the following characteristics: an ammunition magazine outside the pistol grip, a threaded barrel for attachments, a shroud for hand protection, a weight of 50 ounces or more, or be a semiautomatic version of an automatic firearm. A semiautomatic assault weapon is defined as a firearm that is not suitable for sporting purposes and has at least 2 of the following characteristics: a folding or telescoping stock, a conspicuously protruding pistol grip, a fixed magazine capacity exceeding 6 rounds, or the ability to accept a detachable magazine. The legislation includes the designation of semiautomatic assault weapons and penalties for violations. It also addresses the identification markings for these weapons and prohibits large capacity ammunition feeding devices. The legislation prohibits the transfer or possession of large capacity ammunition feeding devices, with exceptions for government agencies, pre-existing lawful possession, and transfers by licensed dealers. The legislation prohibits the transfer or possession of large capacity ammunition feeding devices, with exceptions for licensed manufacturers or importers for testing purposes authorized by the Secretary. The term 'large capacity ammunition feeding device' is defined as a device that can hold more than 10 rounds of ammunition, excluding certain tubular devices. The legislation prohibits possession of large capacity ammunition feeding devices, defined as holding more than 10 rounds, with exceptions for licensed manufacturers. Amendments include defining these devices as firearms and requiring identification markings with serial numbers. The legislation requires large capacity ammunition feeding devices to have a serial number indicating they were manufactured or imported after a certain date, along with additional identification as specified by the Secretary.
